case_name: Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal v. Kamal Behari Lal Singha

facts.text: Civil Appeals Nos. 1667 to 1673 of 1968 were filed in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeals Nos. 1667 to 1673 to 1968. Appeals from the judgment and order dated August

facts.text: Appeals arise from judgment and order dated August 30, 1967 of Calcutta High Court in Income-tax Reference Nos. 3, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10 and 11 of 1964.

anchor.surface_text: 30, 1967 of the Calcutta High Court in Income-tax Reference Nos. 3, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10 and II of 1964. D. Sharma, for the appellant

facts.text: Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal filed these appeals on certificate from High Court.

anchor.surface_text: The Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal aggrieved by this decisions has brought these appeals to this Court on the strength of the certificates given by the High Court.

facts.text: Facts in each appeal are similar; facts set out for Kamal Behari Lal Singha case.

anchor.surface_text: As facts in each of these appeals are more or less similar, it is sufficient if we set out the facts in the case of Kamal Behari Lal Singha,

facts.text: Assessment year for Kamal Behari Lal Singha is 1950-51, corresponding accounting year 1356 B.S. ending April 13, 1950.

anchor.surface_text: for the assessment year 1950-51, the companyresponding accounting year being 1356 B. S. ending On April 13, 1950. It is said that Kamal Behari Lal Singha,

facts.text: Kamal Behari Lal Singha was a shareholder in Ukhara Estate Zamindaries Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: It is said that Kamal Behari Lal Singha, who will hereinafter be referred to as the assessee was a shareholder in the Ukhara Estate Zamindaries Ltd.

facts.text: Assessee received Rs. 13,200 as dividend from Ukhara Estate Zamindaries Ltd.

anchor.surface_text: to be hereinafter referred to as the companypany . During the relevant accounting year, the assessee received a sum of Rs. 13,200 as dividend from the said companypany.

facts.text: Dividend was declared on October 19, 1949.

anchor.surface_text: The said dividend was declared on October 19, 1949. Out of that amount a sum of Rs. 8,829 was paid out of the accumulated capital gains,

facts.text: Rs. 8,829 of dividend paid out of accumulated capital gains received by company as selamis and land acquisition compensation after March 31, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: Out of that amount a sum of Rs. 8,829 was paid out of the accumulated capital gains, received by the companypany in the shape of Selamis and land acquisition companypensation receipts after March 31, 1948.

facts.text: Capital gains taken to reserve fund and thereafter distributed as dividends.

anchor.surface_text: Such capital gains were taken to the reserve fund and thereafter distributed as dividends. The remainder of the dividends was paid out of the balance of the profit

facts.text: Remainder of dividends paid out of balance of profit and loss account.

anchor.surface_text: The remainder of the dividends was paid out of the balance of the profit and loss account In these appeals the dispute centers round the taxability

facts.text: Dispute centers on taxability of share of dividend paid out of capital gains in hands of assessee.

anchor.surface_text: In these appeals the dispute centers round the taxability of that share of the dividend which has been paid out of the capital gains in the hands, of the companypany.

facts.text: Income-tax Officer held dividend from capital gains taxable as dividend.

anchor.surface_text: The Income-tax Officer came to the companyclusion that numberdividend distributed can be companysidered as having been paid out of the capital gains of the companypany, therefore the same is taxable as dividend.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner held Rs. 8,829 not dividend under s.2(6A) but taxable as income in hands of assessee.

anchor.surface_text: In appeal the Appellate Assistant Commissioner accepted the companytention of the assessee that the receipt of Rs. 8,829cannot be companysidered as dividend within the meaning of s.2  6A  of the Act but he held that the same is taxable

facts.text: Tribunal confirmed order of Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: as income in the hands of the assessee. The Tribunal company- firmed the order of the Appellate Assistant Commissioner It is number well settled

facts.text: High Court disagreed with authorities and Tribunal, answered questions in favor of assessees.

anchor.surface_text: But disagreeing with the,, view taken by these authorities ,the High Court answered both these questions in favour -of the assessees.

facts.text: Ukhara Estate Zamindaries Ltd. received selamis for grant of long-term leases after March 31, 1948.

facts.text: Ukhara Estate Zamindaries Ltd. received land acquisition compensation after March 31, 1948.

anchor.surface_text: sation received by the Ukhara Estate Zamindaries Ltd. after 31st March, 1948 was in the hands of the assessee, receipt of dividend within the meaning of Section 2 A  of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922 ?

facts.text: In prior case Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal v. Nalin Behari Lall Singha, assessee was shareholder in same company; similar receipts held not dividends.

anchor.surface_text: So far as the first question set out earlier is companycerned the same is settled by the decision of this Court in Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal v. Nalin Behari Lall Singha  1 .

facts.text: Supreme Court dismissed the appeals with costs.

anchor.surface_text: In the result these appeals fail and they are dismissed with companyts-hearing fee one set.

issues.text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case the Tribunal was right in holding that the distribution to the assessee of the amount attributable to land acquisition compensation received by the Ukhara Estate Zamindaries Ltd. after 31st March, 1948 was in the hands of the assessee, receipt of dividend within the meaning of Section 2(6A) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922?

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and in the circum- stances of the case of Tribunal was right in holding that the distribution to the assessee of the amount attributable to land acquisition companypensation received by the Ukhara Estate Zamindaries Ltd. after 31st March, 1948 was in the hands of the assessee, receipt of dividend within the meaning of

issues.text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case the Tribunal was right in holding that the receipt by the assessee of the amount attributable to selamis realised by the Ukhara Estate Zamindaries Ltd., for grant of long-term leases after 31st March, 1948 was a receipt of income of the assessee and taxable as the income of the assessee from other sources?

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case the Tribunal was right in holding that the receipt by the assessee of the amount attributable to selamis realised by the Ukhara Estate Zamindaries Ltd., for grant of long-term leases after 31st March, 1948 was a receipt of income of the assessee and tax,able as the income of the assessee from other sources?

arguments.court_reasoning: Receipt is capital in hands of assessee as they are beneficially entitled to company's capital

arguments.claim: The nature of a receipt is determined entirely by its character in the hands of the receiver, not the payer

In other words, the nature of receipt is determined entirely by its character in the hands of the receiver

arguments.claim: Distributions similar to those in these appeals are not dividends

anchor.surface_text: So far as the first question set out earlier is concerned the same is settled by the decision of this Court in Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal v. Nalin Behari Lall Singha. The assessee therein was also one of the shareholders of Ukhara Estate Zamindaries Ltd.

arguments.claim: If the recipient is beneficially entitled to the capital, payments out of capital are capital receipts even if received as income

anchor.surface_text: Coming back to the question how exactly to draw the line between a capital receipt and a revenue receipt in cases of the type that are before us, one can do no better than refer to the observations of Finley J. in Trustees of the Will of H. K. Brodie deceased v. Commissioner Inland Revenue.

arguments.claim: The assessees as shareholders were beneficially entitled to the capital of the company including salamis and land acquisition compensation, so the distribution is a capital receipt

anchor.surface_text: But, I think, the governing consideration is this the question being, was the sum received as income, one has to consider what was the source from which it was received and what were the circumstances in which it was received. ... The assessees were shareholders in the company. They were beneficially entitled to the capital of the company.

arguments.claim: The fact that sums were distributed as dividends does not change their true nature as capital receipts

anchor.surface_text: Therefore when that sum was distributed amongst the shareholders of the company, each of the shareholders took a share of the capital ... That being so the receipt with which we are concerned in these appeals must also be considered as capital receipt. The fact that those sums were distributed as dividends does not change the true nature of the receipt.

holdings.text: The distribution to the assessee of the amount attributable to land acquisition compensation received by the Ukhara Estate Zamindaries Ltd. after 31st March, 1948 is not a receipt of dividend within the meaning of Section 2(6A) of the Indian Income-tax Act, 1922.

anchor.surface_text: So far as the first question set out earlier is concerned the same is settled by the decision of this Court in Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal v. Nalin Behari Lall Singha 1 . The assessee therein was also one of the share- holders of Ukhara Estate Zamindaries Ltd. His case was no different from that of the respondents herein. But the only point that arose for decision in that appeal was whether the receipts similar to those we are considering here can be considered as dividends? This Court answered that question in the negative.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Directly settled by binding precedent of this Court in Commissioner of Income-tax, West Bengal v. Nalin Behari Lall Singha where similar receipts held not dividends.

holdings.text: The receipt by the assessee of the amount attributable to selamis realised by the Ukhara Estate Zamindaries Ltd. for grant of long-term leases after 31st March, 1948 is not a receipt of income taxable as income from other sources.

anchor.surface_text: The assessees were shareholders in the company. They were beneficially entitled to the capital of the company. The amount with which we are concerned in these appeals was received by the company as Salamis and as compensation for the acquisition of the lands of the company. ... Therefore when that sum was distributed amongst the shareholders of the company, each of the shareholders took a share of the capital ... That being so the receipt with which we are concerned in these appeals must also be considered as capital receipt. The fact that those sums were distributed as dividends does not change the true nature of the receipt.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Nature of receipt determined in hands of recipient who as shareholder is beneficially entitled to company's capital; amounts are capital receipts for company passed to shareholders as capital; applies Brodie principle on source and entitlement.

holdings.text: The nature of a receipt is determined entirely by its character in the hands of the receiver and not by its nature in the hands of the payer.

anchor.surface_text: It is now well settled that in order to find out whether a receipt is a capital receipt or a Revenue receipt one has to see what it is in the hands of the receiver and not its nature in the hands of the payer. In other words, the nature of receipt is determined entirely by its character in the hands of the receiver and the source from which the payment is made has no bearing on the question.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Well-settled principle applied to facts; payer's characterization (capital gains) irrelevant; focus on recipient's position as shareholder entitled to capital.

holdings.text: The observations in Trustees of the Will of H. K. Brodie v. Commissioner Inland Revenue correctly set out the law on distinguishing capital and revenue receipts based on beneficial entitlement to capital versus income.

anchor.surface_text: Coming back to the question how exactly to draw the line between a capital receipt and a revenue receipt in cases of the type that are before us, one can do no better than refer to the observations of Finley J. in Trustees of the Will of H. K. Brodie deceased v. Commissioner Inland Revenue ... The above observations, in our opinion, correctly set out the law.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Endorses foreign precedent as accurately stating governing test: consider source, circumstances, and whether recipient beneficially entitled to capital or only income.

holdings.text: A receipt is what it is and not what it is called; distribution labelled as dividend does not change its nature as capital receipt if shareholder beneficially entitled to capital.

anchor.surface_text: That being so the receipt with which we are concerned in these appeals must also be considered as capital receipt. The fact that those sums were distributed as dividends does not change the true nature of the receipt. A receipt is what it is and not what it is called.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Substance over form; label 'dividend' irrelevant when true character is return of capital to entitled shareholders.

precedents.case_name: Trustees of the Will of H. K. Brodie (deceased) v. Commissioner of Inland Revenue
precedents.cited_proposition: to draw the line between a capital receipt and a revenue receipt, consider the source from which it was received and the circumstances; if capital belongs to the receiver, payments out of it are capital; if capital belongs to someone else but received as income, it is income
precedents.cited_holding: But, I think, the governing consideration is this the question being, was the sum received as income, one has to consider what was the source from which it was received and what were the circumstances in which it was received. If the capital belonged to the person receiving the sums... they are income and not the less income because in the hands of somebody else capital.
